breathing.title: Breathing Exercise
breathing.description: Controlled breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system, naturally reducing anxiety and stress. This simple yet powerful technique can be practiced anywhere, anytime.

calm.title: Calm
calm.description: Lower heart rate and blood pressure

focus.title: Focus
focus.description: More oxygen to brain for clearer thinking

completion.title: Excellent Work
completion.description: You've completed {count} breathing cycles in {time}. Your parasympathetic nervous system has been activated, promoting relaxation.

whatHappens.title: What happens in your body
whatHappens.description: Controlled breathing through the 4:6 pattern which emphasizes a longer exhalation stimulates the vagus nerve, a primary component of the parasympathetic nervous system. Activating this nerve sends signals that help transition the body from a "fight or flight" state to a "rest and repair" mode.

inhale.title: 4-Second Inhale
inhale.description: Steady breathing in brings fresh oxygen to your brain and helps you focus.

exhale.title: 6-Second Exhale
exhale.description: The longer out-breath signals your body to slow down and relax.

clinical.title: Clinical Research
clinical.description: Research demonstrates that diaphragmatic breathing significantly reduces both physiological and psychological stress markers. Slow-paced breathing at six breaths per minute increases heart rate variability, a key indicator of stress resilience.

therapeutic.title: Therapeutic Use
therapeutic.description: This controlled breathing technique reduces cortisol levels and is widely used in anxiety treatment and stress management. In a 12-week clinical study, participants practicing diaphragmatic breathing saw anxiety scores decrease by 4.85 points on the GAD-7 scale.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: Start your day with energizing 4-4-6 breathing
Use box breathing before important meetings or presentations
Quick reset breathing during stressful moments

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Immediate calming effect within the first minute
Slower heart rate and reduced muscle tension
Better stress resilience with regular practice

posture.title: Posture
posture.description: Sit or stand straight to allow full lung expansion. Shoulders relaxed, not hunched.

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: Find a quiet space where you won't be interrupted. Comfortable temperature helps focus.

consistency.title: Consistency
consistency.description: Practice the same technique for a week before switching. Building familiarity improves effectiveness.

neurological.title: Neurological Impact
neurological.description: The 5-4-3-2-1 technique redirects attention from internal anxious thoughts to external sensory experiences. This engages your prefrontal cortex while calming the amygdalaâ€”your brain's alarm system. By systematically using your five senses, you activate present-moment awareness and break the cycle of anxious thinking patterns.

stability.title: Immediate Stability
stability.description: The structured sequence (5 things to see, 4 to touch, etc.) gives your mind a concrete focus during chaotic mental states, preventing further spiraling into anxiety. This technique provides immediate grounding by connecting you with your physical environment and current reality.

clinical.title: Clinical Research
clinical.description: Research published in the Journal of Clinical Psychology demonstrates that sensory-based grounding techniques significantly reduce acute anxiety symptoms within 3-5 minutes. The 5-4-3-2-1 method specifically engages the brain's attentional networks, helping regulate emotional responses during stress.

therapeutic.title: Therapeutic Use
therapeutic.description: Grounding techniques are widely used in trauma therapy, anxiety treatment, and panic disorder management as evidence-based interventions. Studies show regular practice improves overall emotional regulation and reduces the frequency of panic attacks.

whenToPractice.title: When to practice
items: During panic attacks or overwhelming anxiety

whatYoullNotice.title: What you'll notice
items: Immediate calming effect within the first minute
Better stress resilience with regular practice

timing.title: Timing
timing.description: Don't rush through the steps. Spend time really observing each sense.

detail.title: Detail
detail.description: Notice details like colors, textures, temperatures, and specific sounds.

practice.title: Practice
practice.description: Use this technique even when calm to build familiarity for anxious moments.
